children.name: in the same place with another person
together
children.definition: /təˈgedəʳ/  cùng nhau , với nhau
examples: ▪ Nicola and I were at school together.
▪ Each year the whole family spends Christmas together.
▪ For years, these people who are now at war lived together very peacefully.
▪ We’d better stay together, or we might get lost.

children.name: side by side
children.definition: live  if peoplelive side by side,they live togetherpeacefullyeven though there arebigdifferencesbetween them:
examples: ▪ It was a great experience - people from so many very different backgrounds living side by side.
▪ The Muslim residents say they are ready and willing to live side by side with their neighbors again.

children.name: with
children.definition: /wɪð, wɪθ/

children.name: với , cùng với
examples: ▪ Don’t leave me alone with her.

children.name: ▪ ‘Where’s Jill?’ ‘I don’t know, I thought she was with you.’
examples: ▪ I try to make sure I have a couple of hours to spend with David every evening.
▪ We live with my parents-in-law.
▪ At the moment, she’s in a meeting with the President.

children.name: arrive/leave/go out etc with somebody
examples: ▪ Lindsay arrived with her husband but left by herself.
▪ I saw Rick go out of the building with Susan.

children.name: company
children.definition: the presence of another person or other people, that gives you someone to talk to and stops you feeling lonely:sự cùng đi, cùng ở, bầu bạn
examples: The two menenjoyeach other’scompany.
Come over for dinner – Icould use the company(= would like to be with other people ).

children.name: enjoy sb’s company
examples: Steve was fun and she clearly enjoyed his company.

children.name: keep sb company
children.definition: be with someone so that they do not feel lonely
examples: Mum was out so I stayed at home to keep my younger sister company.

children.name: have some company
children.definition: not be alone
examples: ‘Come in,’ she said, pleased to have some company.

children.name: need/want company
examples: Children need the company of other kids their age.

children.name: be good/pleasant company
children.definition: be a cheerful person who is enjoyable to be with
examples: I always liked seeing Rob – he was such good company.

children.name: do something for the company
examples: I go to French evening classes, for the company as much as for the French.

children.name: miss somebody’s company
examples: Now that she’s gone, I really miss her company.

children.name: as company
examples: Bessie was glad to have the dog as company.
in sb’s company/in the company of sth when you are with a particular person:
I felt nervous in the company of such an important man.
I always feel very relaxed in Nick’s company.
Many people are uneasy in the company of strangers.

children.name: in company with somebody(= together with another person or group )
examples: He’s performing in company with saxophonist Ernie Watts.

children.name: in sb’s presence
children.definition: if you arein someone’s presence,especially someoneimportantorfamous, you are with them or in the same place as them:với sự có mặt của
examples: ▪ What was it like to be actually in the Queen’s presence?
in the presence of somebody
▪ I could think of very little to say in the presence of so many important people

children.name: doing sth with another person/ group etc
together
children.definition: /təˈgeðəʳ/
examples: There’s no point in taking two cars - let’s go together.
The police and army worked together to track down the terrorists.

children.name: in partnership with
children.definition: /ɪn ˈpɑːʳtnəʳʃɪp wɪð/  if people, organizations, or countries work in partnership with each other, they work together to do something important or useful:

children.name: kết hợp với
examples: ▪ The city council is working in partnership with local businesses to build new sports facilities in the area.

children.name: side by side
children.definition: if twogroupswork or fightside by side, they work closely together to achieve something, even though there may bebig differencesbetween them:cùng nhau, sát cánh
examples: ▪ It was a strange situation with Washington, Pretoria and Peking fighting side by side.

children.name: side by side with
examples: ▪ Soldiers worked side by side with civilians to rebuild the city.

children.name: with
children.definition: /wɪð, wɪθ/
examples: ▪ My family and I went camping in the mountains with some old friends of ours.
▪ I’d like you to work with the person sitting beside you and see if we can come up with some new ideas,

children.name: collectively
children.definition: if people do somethingcollectively,they do it by working together asequalmembers of an organized group:chung tay , cùng nhau
examples: ▪ The team collectively must decide what resources they need and how they are to be used.
▪ Individually, people have little power, but collectively they can be more influential.

children.name: jointly
children.definition: jointly managed/owned/published/funded etcbysb : managed, owned etc by two or more people or organizations working together equally:cùng nhau, cùng chung
examples: ▪ The business is jointly owned and run by six TV companies.
▪ It was a major research project, jointly funded by the university and the Health Department.

children.name: in collaboration with
children.definition: if you work on a plan or do somethingin collaboration withanother person or organization, you work verycloselywith them in order to achieve it:cộng tác với, với sự hợp tác của
examples: ▪ I wrote the article in collaboration with a number of my colleagues.
▪ This course has been developed in collaboration with major professional bodies involved in the financial services sector.

children.name: shoulder to shoulder
children.definition: with sb if one group of peoplestandsorfightsshoulder to shoulder withanother group of people, they support them or fight together with themagainst an enemy: sát cánh
examples: ▪ British soldiers fought shoulder to shoulder with American and French troops.
▪ Mitterrand, although a socialist, stood shoulder to shoulder with the NATO allies during the challenges of the early 1980s.

children.name: in conjunction with
children.definition: if something is done by one organization or group of peoplein conjunction withanother organization or group, it is done by both of them working together: kết hợp với
examples: ▪ The exhibition is sponsored by the Arts Council in conjunction with British Airways.
▪ Stenmann is working in conjunction with leading scientists and has invested $5 million in the scheme.

children.name: joint
children.definition: /dʒɔɪnt/ a joint decision, statement, effort, report etcis made by people or groups working together, not by just one of them:
examples: ( quyết định/lời tuyên bố/nỗ lực/báo cao... ) chung
▪ We both wanted to move to Canada - it was a joint decision.
▪ a joint declaration by Israeli and Palestinian leaders
a joint effort : sự chung sức, nỗ lực chung
▪ ‘Did you cook the dinner, Jane?’ ‘No, it was a joint effort.’

children.name: combined
children.definition: /kəmˈbaɪnd/ combined actionsare done by people or groups who try to do something together which they could not do alone:

children.name: kết hợp
examples: ▪ The combined efforts of four police officers and two paramedics were needed to lift the driver from the wreckage.
▪ It was a combined operation involving troops from the US and Europe.

children.name: collective
children.definition: /kəˈlektɪv/ a collective decision, action, or agreementis made by everyone in a group or organization, not by just one or two of its members:
examples: ( quyết định, hành động, thỏa thuận ) tập thể
▪ A jury’s verdict is the result of a collective agreement.
▪ Kerry called the labor laws ‘a legitimate collective effort to protect our children’ and said he supported them.
collective responsibility (for something)
when everyone in a group shares responsibility for its decisions and actions
▪ The bureau was without a manager for some time, so the staff took collective responsibility for all the tasks.

children.name: collaborative
children.definition: /kəˈlæbərətɪvǁ-reɪ-/  use this about an activity that involves people working together, especially in order to achieve something that will bring an advantage to both of them:
examples: chung, kết hợp
a collaborative effort : sự nỗ lực chung
▪ A manager’s main task is to coordinate the collaborative efforts of a number of people.
collaborative project/research/venture etc : dự án / nghiên cứu / kinh doanh mạo hiểm chung
▪ The new system was the product of a collaborative project between Apple and IBM.
▪ a collaborative youth training program involving several businesses

children.name: to be together again after being separated
be back together
children.definition: /biː ˌbæk təˈgeðəʳ/  to be together again after being separated, used especially aboutcoupleswho have started a romantic relationship again:

children.name: trở lại với nhau ( thường nói về các cặp đôi yêu nhau )
examples: ▪ Did you know that Denise and Jonathon are back together?
▪ It’s so nice to have all the family back together again.

children.name: be back together with
examples: ▪ I’m back together with Johnny now and things are going pretty well.

children.name: get back together
examples: ▪ Jack wants to get back together, but I’ve really had enough.

children.name: be reunited
children.definition: /biː ˌriːjuːˈnaɪtd/  to be brought together again with someone that youlostor wereunable to seefor a long time, especially whensomeone helps youto be with them again:
examples: được đoàn tụ ( sau nhiều năm ko gặp được nhau hay mất tích , thường có ai đó đã giúp bạn đoàn tụ )
▪ After 50 years apart, the twin sisters were eventually reunited.
be reunited with : được đoàn tụ với
▪ In the early hours of this morning, the hostages were reunited with their families at Point Reach airbase

children.name: with another thing or other things
with
children.definition: /wɪð, wɪθ/

children.name: với, cùng với
examples: ▪ I’ve put our passports in your handbag with the travellers cheques.
▪ I hope you haven’t thrown that letter out with the garbage!

children.name: ▪ a traditional Christmas dinner of roast turkey with all the trimmings
together
children.definition: /təˈgeðəʳ/ togetherin the same place, or addedtogether,not separately:

children.name: với nhau , cùng với
examples: ▪ Mix the butter and the sugar together.
▪ That skirt and jacket look really good together.
▪ Together these two paintings are worth more than $10,000.

children.name: along with
children.definition: /əˈlɒŋ wɪðǁəˈlɔːŋ-/  in thesameplaceas another thing or other things:

children.name: cùng với
examples: ▪ I keep my insurance policy in the top drawer, along with my other important documents.
▪ Put it over there along with the other presents.

children.name: come with U
children.partOfSpeech: [transitive phrasal verb not in progressive or passive]
children.definition: come with/ˈkʌm wɪð/  if something that youbuycomeswithsomething else, it is sold with an additional object that is included in the price:

children.name: đi kèm với ( được bao gồm trong giá )
examples: ▪ Every new camera comes with a leather case and free film.
▪ All the main courses come with salad and chips.
▪ We have 5000 log cabins to rent. All come with their own private sauna.

children.name: accompany
children.definition: to be provided or exist at the same time as something:
examples: be accompanied by
The course books are accompanied by four CDs.
Depression is almost always accompanied by insomnia.
The salmon was accompanied by(= served with)a fresh green salad.
Your passport application form should be accompanied by two recent photographs.
accompanying[attri] an accompanying book, document etc, is one that you get together with something that you buy, and which gives you more information about it: đi kèm
accompanying booklet/volume/letter etc
Please see accompanying booklet for instructions.
The video recorder has an accompanying booklet which contains full instructions.
Each coursebook has an accompanying workbook for grammar practice.
Please see accompanying booklet for instructions.

children.name: when sth is used together with sth else
together
children.definition: /təˈgeðəʳ/  cùng nhau , với nhau
examples: ▪ The shampoo and conditioner should be used together for the best possible result.
▪ When you’re slowing down, use the gears and the brakes together.

children.name: together with
children.definition: alsoalong withUS B2 cùng với , kết hợp với
examples: ▪ A sensible diet along with regular exercise is the best way to lose weight.
▪ I love Italian food, together with a good bottle of red wine.

children.name: combined with
children.definition: if atreatment, method, drug etcis combined withanother, it is used with it because this will have the most effect:
examples: ▪ Small children need firmness combined with loving care.
▪ The standard treatment is surgery, often combined with radiation.

children.name: in combination
children.definition: if two or morethingsormethodsare used in combination, they are used together at the same time, in order to achieve a particular effect:
examples: ▪ The drug company recommended using Losec in combination with antibiotics for the treatment of ulcers.

children.name: in combination with
examples: ▪ The flavor of paprika, in combination with sour cream, is used in many Eastern European cuisines.

children.name: in conjunction with
children.definition: if one thing is used in conjunction with another, it is used with it, in order to help you do sth more easily: chung với , kèm với , kết hợp với
examples: ▪ Learners will benefit from using the book in conjunction with the video.
▪ The file viewing functions can be used in conjunction with file manager.

children.name: alongside
children.definition: different types of things, methods, ideas etc that are used or existalongsideeach other, are beingusedtogether orexisttogether at the same time:
examples: The new advertisement will be broadcast alongside AMV’s two existing commercials during prime time viewing.
Only the island of Bali preserved, alongside its own traditions, the Brahman heritage of those ancient times.

children.name: compatible
children.definition: different machines, methods, ideas etc that are compatiblecanexisttogether or beusedtogether without producing problems:tương hợp , tương thích
examples: ▪ Certain kinds of drug are not compatible and should never be taken together.
▪ The two businesses have compatible aims, and a merger would be to everyone’s advantage.

children.name: compatible with
examples: ▪ Unfortunately he bought a printer that was not compatible with his computer.

children.name: several differentthings or people considered as a group
together
children.definition: ▪ The Executive, Legislative, and Judiciary branches  make up the US government.

children.name: taken togetherconsidered as a group
examples: ▪ Taken together, these measures should ensure a rapid return to financial stability.

children.name: collectively
children.definition: cùng với nhau
examples: ▪ Collectively, these studies showed a clear link between smoking and cancer.

children.name: collectively called/collectively known as/collectively referred to as etc
examples: ▪ Belgium, Luxembourg, and the Netherlands are collectively known as the "Benelux' countries.
▪ These substances are referred to collectively as ketone bodies.

children.name: teamwork
children.definition: noun

children.name: when a group of people work well together
examples: _Brilliant teamwork and old fashioned grit got the team a last minute point.
_Her determination, teamwork skills and leadership capabilities convinced us that she was perfect for the job.
